title: Quiz 7: Obstetric Emergencies (PPH, Eclampsia)
topicName: Unit Three Part One: Labour and Puerperium
description: Postpartum hemorrhage, eclampsia, and life-threatening obstetric emergencies

questions.question: What is the definition of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH)?

options.text: Blood loss > 300 ml after vaginal delivery
Blood loss > 500 ml after vaginal delivery or > 1000 ml after cesarean
Blood loss > 1000 ml after any delivery

questions.explanation: Postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) is defined as blood loss exceeding 500 ml after vaginal delivery or 1000 ml after cesarean delivery. It is a leading cause of maternal mortality worldwide.
questions.hint: The threshold differs for vaginal versus cesarean delivery.

questions.question: What are the '4 Ts' mnemonic for causes of postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.explanation: The '4 Ts' mnemonic for causes of PPH are: Tone (uterine atony), Trauma (genital tract trauma), Tissue (retained placental tissue), and Thrombin (coagulation disorders).
questions.hint: Each T represents a different cause mechanism.

questions.question: Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage.
questions.explanation: True. Uterine atony (failure of the uterus to contract properly after delivery) is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage, accounting for approximately 70-80% of cases.
questions.hint: This occurs when the uterus doesn't contract effectively.

questions.question: Which of the following are components of active management of the third stage of labour to prevent PPH? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Uterine massage after delivery of placenta

questions.explanation: Active management of the third stage includes: uterotonic drugs (oxytocin), controlled cord traction, and uterine massage after placental delivery. These interventions significantly reduce PPH risk.
questions.hint: Focus on interventions that help the uterus contract and deliver the placenta.

questions.question: Match each 'T' cause of PPH with its description:
questions.explanation: Tone = uterine atony, Trauma = genital tract injury (lacerations), Tissue = retained placental tissue, Thrombin = coagulation disorders. Each requires specific management.
questions.hint: Each T represents a different pathophysiological mechanism.

questions.question: The first-line treatment for uterine atony is ___BLANK___ and ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: The first-line treatment for uterine atony is uterine massage combined with uterotonic medications, particularly oxytocin. If these measures are ineffective, additional interventions may be required.
questions.hint: One is a physical technique, one is a medication.

questions.question: What is the definition of eclampsia?

options.text: Convulsions in a woman with preeclampsia

questions.explanation: Eclampsia is defined as the occurrence of convulsions (seizures) in a woman with preeclampsia. It is a life-threatening complication that requires immediate medical attention.
questions.hint: This involves seizures in a woman with preeclampsia.

questions.question: What is the primary drug used to prevent and treat eclamptic seizures?
questions.explanation: Magnesium sulfate is the primary drug used to prevent and treat eclamptic seizures. It is more effective than other anticonvulsants and also has vasodilatory effects that help improve placental perfusion.
questions.hint: This mineral is the drug of choice for eclampsia.

questions.question: Uterine inversion is a life-threatening obstetric emergency requiring immediate manual replacement.
questions.explanation: True. Uterine inversion is a life-threatening obstetric emergency where the uterus turns inside out. It requires immediate manual replacement of the uterus, along with uterotonic medications and fluid resuscitation.
questions.hint: This is when the uterus turns inside out during delivery.

questions.question: What is the management for amniotic fluid embolism?
questions.explanation: Management of amniotic fluid embolism is primarily supportive, including oxygen therapy, hemodynamic support, blood product replacement for coagulopathy, and immediate delivery if the fetus is still alive. There is no specific treatment for AFE.
questions.hint: This condition has no specific cure, only supportive measures.
